title: Diploma in Reception Skills
headline: Learn how to perform the duties of a receptionist effectively in this free online office administration training course.
description: Do you consider yourself to be productive and organised? Are you good at multitasking, meeting deadlines and working with people? If so, you might make a superb receptionist who assists with key roles and services to ensure smooth running of your organisation’s offices. This administration training course teaches you how to meet your responsibilities as one of many types of receptionist and explains how to improve workplace health and safety.

courseDescription:
Receptionists are key members of their organisations and ensure smooth office operations. This administration course comprehensively explains the various skills and career progressions of a receptionist. We begin by introducing you to the basic concepts important to those who work in reception. We examine the different types of receptionist and compare their roles. Top-tier receptionists are expected to communicate effectively because they are the first point of contact with customers, both face-to-face and over the phone, and they play an important role in making a good first impression. We provide effective communication skills and discuss good telephone etiquette. We distinguish between formal and informal messages and emphasise the importance of confidentiality when taking and sending messages. Receptionists are privy to a lot of sensitive information and need to be discreet and skilled in managing it. We outline the basics of database management and show you how to ensure confidentiality with data.

As a receptionist, you may be required to make a variety of bookings or reservations. We provide effective scheduling techniques to help you manage reservations and other routine administrative tasks. The course compares the duties of a receptionist and those of a secretary. We then study filing systems to help you master the important task of managing them. Occupational health and safety is crucial to many industries and we explain how to prevent workplace accidents and protect your colleagues from risk. The course then provides the techniques required to make meetings successful, from arranging accommodation for attendees to record-keeping and writing minutes. Your grasp on organisational skills like time management will ensure that your office runs smoothly and efficiently.

The course examines the use of information technology in administrative work and identifies the software packages that are useful to a receptionist. We explore the concept of teamwork and relate it to the role of a receptionist who is a good team player. The reception area of an office in any industry plays a key role in making a first impression and must appear welcoming and professional to visitors. We therefore show you how to make yours more appealing and impressive to customers. A receptionist job keeps you busy and serves as a perfect springboard to further career progression. This course has no prerequisites and is intended for anyone who wants to be a receptionist. It also suits current administrators who want to improve their skills. Sign up to turn your talent for organisation and working with people into a rewarding career.

Start Course Now

Once you have completed this diploma course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison diploma is:

  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital diploma: a downloadable diploma in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked diploma, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked diploma in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Receptionist Role and Essence of Communication
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the role and duties of a receptionist. We’ll show you the types of receptionists and the differences between them. You’ll learn how to create a good first impression, how to communicate effectively, how to practice good telephone skills and how to ensure confidentiality when taking and sending messages.
topics: Receptionist Role and Essence of Communication - Learning Outcomes
Receptionist Role and Essence of Communication - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module will teach you database management, including how to ensure confidentiality in database management and how to effectively handle reservations. You will learn about filing systems, routine administrative tasks that a receptionist should perform, and health and safety considerations at work.
topics: Database Management, Security & Safety Issues - Learning Outcomes
Database Management, Security & Safety Issues - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you’ll be introduced to the concept of confidentiality, why it is important and the consequences of breaching it. You’ll be taught the pre-arrangements to make to ensure that a meeting is successful. Upon that, we’ll teach you how to be organised and prioritise as well as how to carry out effective business communication.
topics: Business Communication and Time management - Learning Outcomes
Business Communication and Time management - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Importance of Technology and Team Work
modules.description: In this module, you will learn how technology plays a crucial part in administrative work and the software packages that are useful to a receptionist. We’ll teach you teamwork and its importance and how to make a reception area look welcoming and professional. In addition, we'll show you a receptionist's potential future career paths.
topics: Importance of Technology and Team Work - Learning Outcomes
Important of Technology in Reception Work
To Sum It All Up: Reception Work Explained
Importance of Technology and Team Work - Lesson Summary

topics: Diploma in Reception Skills - Course Assessment

slides:
• Learning Outcomes 

  • Upon completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Define who is a receptionist.
    • Highlight the importance of a good appearance and personal hygiene.
    • Describe the types of receptionists that exist.
    • List the duties and responsibilities of a receptionist.
    • Identify customer needs.
    • Analyse procedures to manage difficult situations and clients.
    • Explain the appropriate language to use during a professional telephone call.
    • Compare formal messages and informal messages.

  • What Is a Receptionist?

  • A general a broad overview, a receptionist can be defined as: “An individual serving as the first point of contact in an office or building".

    Whilst this may seem quite a broad, sweeping generalisation because there are many other duties that go along with the job role, this definition basically sums up the most pertinent point of the job role. 

    Think about it - a receptionist receives guests, whether they are reps, customers, clients, business associates, new employees, prospective employees, people simply wanting a query answering, and everything in-between, and they field their questions and queries to the appropriate person or destination. 

    Of course, a receptionist doesn't only receive guests in person, they receive them in the form of telephone queries as well.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • One of the most important parts of a receptionist's role is effective communication,  this basically tells you how important communication is in this job role.

    As the receptionist, you are the face of the company; you are the first person anyone walking into the building will see, and because of that, you have a huge responsibility on your shoulders.

  • The Different Types of Receptionists

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • You might think that a receptionist is the same in any organisation, no matter where they work, where they are located, what the business deals with, and the types of people the receptionist will come into contact with every day.
    Wrong!

  • There are subtle differences between the duties and the approach that must be taken into account when it comes to where a receptionist works, and there are even examples of places where a receptionist needs to be a little more specialised, e.g. a legal or medical receptionist. 

    In this section, we will discuss the different types of receptionists there are; whilst it is impossible to come up with an exhaustive list, we will cover the main areas of specialism and explain the duties you might come in to contact with, the different approaches you may need to have, as well as any other subtle differences between them.

    The importance of this is evident in every kind of reception job, no matter where it is your work; however, there are some differences between certain specialisms.

  • Communication and First Impression

    • New Tab
    • How to Communicate With People
    • The Principles to Create a Powerful First Impression
    • Enter your text here..
      Enter your text here..
      Customer ID
      Customer Name
    • We know that in any job, when dealing with the general public, communication is one of the most vital parts of the whole shebang. How you speak to someone is one of the most important first impressions they will be left with, along with the visual impression they have of you. 

      It is for this reason that one of the most important facets of being an effective receptionist is the ability to communicate effortlessly and confidently, in a high-quality manner, using voice, tone, intelligent language, and all in a very friendly and approachable way. 

      It sounds complicated, but it's actually very easy once you know how, and becomes second nature over time. Learning to speak to people how you would want to be spoken to is a good way to think about it. In this module, we will explore the essential points of communication, giving you helpful advice and tools to use in your day-to-day role, allowing you to make a) the best first impression possible, and b) a difference to the day of your customers and clients. 
      We will also explore some of the downsides of reception work, such as dealing with potentially difficult customers and situations, and explain how to deliver bad news in the most sensitive and constructive way possible.

  • How to Use the Telephone

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • In our last couple of modules, we talked at length about communication. However, most of it was generally to do with face-to-face meetings In these meetings, it is much easier to set a tone and influence the outcome of the conversation, because you can use body language to help guide the discussion in the correct direction. As a receptionist, you will spend a large portion of your time on the telephone, either fielding calls to other departments, or answering queries yourself.
  • If your particular reception desk has a switchboard' facility, then you will need to discover what the caller is requesting, and who is best to deal with their query, before putting them through to that particular person. 

    This could involve a little detective work, and whilst you're figuring it all out, you need to multi-task, keep the caller's attention and also help them feel like you are still listening and paying attention to them, without going silent whilst you try to think about who to put them through to! 

    It can be a tricky situation at times, especially if you're not too sure, but high-quality telephone skills are an essential part of being an effective receptionist; there is no receptionist out there who is lacking in this skill, simply because it is that vital to the job! In this module, we will discuss what good telephone skills entail, how to obtain them, how to ensure the conversation goes in the right direction, and how to learn a few must have phrases when answering and ending a telephone call, and the health and safety issues that go along with using a telephone for a prolonged period of time.

    This could involve a little detective work, and whilst you're figuring it all out, you need to multi-task, keep the caller's attention and also help them feel like you are still listening and paying attention to them, without going silent whilst you try to think about who to put them through to! 

    It can be a tricky situation at times, especially if you're not too sure, but high-quality telephone skills are an essential part of being an effective receptionist; there is no receptionist out there who is lacking in this skill, simply because it is that vital to the job! In this module, we will discuss what good telephone skills entail, how to obtain them, how to ensure the conversation goes in the right direction, and how to learn a few must have phrases when answering and ending a telephone call, and the health and safety issues that go along with using a telephone for a prolonged period of time.

    • In our last module, we talked at great length about telephone skills, and the importance of creating the correct impression via your tone of voice, and the language you use.

      We also briefly touched upon messaging taking, and the ways in which you can take the correct information, without missing out anything important. In this module, we will cover that ground a little more, reiterating the importance of how you handle telephone conversations, whilst also going into more detail about message taking.

      We will talk about the types of messages you may need to take, namely formal messages and informal messages, and explore the differences between them. We will also talk about confidentiality a little more, look at ways you can ensure your message is passed onto the correct person in a timely and secure manner, and learn how to confirm receipt of the message.

    • Message-taking forms such a hugely important part of a receptionist's day-to-day work, so it is proper and correct that we dedicate a whole module to this important process.
      By reading our last module, you will now be au-fait with the importance of telephone skills, as well as how to use your voice and language in order to make the right impression on the caller. We talked in our previous module about how you don't have the gift of body language to help you when discussing an issue over the telephone, as you would have with face to face discussions, and for that reason it is even more important to choose your words carefully, and to keep a clear eye on how your voice sounds, and how it is received by the caller. Picking the correct language and saying the right things is vital, without coming across as cold or uncaring. Whilst this can be a hard line to walk sometimes, with practice it will become second nature, as a professional telephone voice and knowing exactly what to say are two of the most important skills an effective receptionist should have.

    • A person working as a receptionist who doesn't have good quality telephone skills will not last long in this line of work, purely because it is like a window cleaner who can't clean very well; the ability to communicate clearly and precisely is vital in reception work, and this is something which will probably be tested at interview, prior to being hired in a receptionist post. 

      Once you have taken a call and you have found out what it is the caller actually wants or needs, it may be that you need to pass the information onto a different department or a different person on your team, who can help them in a more specific way. If this is the case, you need to identify the type of message you are taking, and make sure you get as much detail as possible. On top of this, always inform the caller of what you are going to do next, e.g. pass the information on to someone who will either contact them by letter/email/call them back, but never make false promises. Always make sure the timescale you give to the caller for them to receive a response is a realistic one.

      The first telephone answering service started in 1923. Hello Inc. in Virginia, US, began under the name of Mrs Smith's Doctors Exchange. A bedridden Margaret Redmond Smith offered to answer calls for local doctors, and operated her business using an old French-style telephone mounted on a scissors-type extension near her bed.

      By reading our last module, you will now be au-fait with the importance of telephone skills, as well as how to use your voice and language in order to make the right impression on the caller. We talked in our previous module about how you don't have the gift of body language to help you when discussing an issue over the telephone, as you would have with face to face discussions, and for that reason it is even more important to choose your words carefully, and to keep a clear eye on how your voice sounds, and how it is received by the caller. Picking the correct language and saying the right things is vital, without coming across as cold or uncaring. Whilst this can be a hard line to walk sometimes, with practice it will become second nature, as a professional telephone voice and knowing exactly what to say are two of the most important skills an effective receptionist should have.

Whilst this can be a hard line to walk sometimes, with practice it will become second nature, as a professional telephone voice and knowing exactly what to say are two of the most important skills an effective receptionist should have.

      Customer Name
    • Other Importance of Quality Telephone Skills
      A person working as a receptionist who doesn't have good quality telephone skills will not last long in this line of work, purely because it is like a window cleaner who can't clean very well; the ability to communicate clearly and precisely is vital in reception work, and this is something which will probably be tested at interview, prior to being hired in a receptionist post. 

      Once you have taken a call and you have found out what it is the caller actually wants or needs, it may be that you need to pass the information onto a different department or a different person on your team, who can help them in a more specific way. If this is the case, you need to identify the type of message you are taking, and make sure you get as much detail as possible. On top of this, always inform the caller of what you are going to do next, e.g. pass the information on to someone who will either contact them by letter/email/call them back, but never make false promises. Always make sure the timescale you give to the caller for them to receive a response is a realistic one.

      The first telephone answering service started in 1923. Hello Inc. in Virginia, US, began under the name of Mrs Smith's Doctors Exchange. A bedridden Margaret Redmond Smith offered to answer calls for local doctors, and operated her business using an old French-style telephone mounted on a scissors-type extension near her bed.

    • In our last module, we talked at great length about telephone skills, and the importance of creating the correct impression via your tone of voice, and the language you use.

      We also briefly touched upon messaging taking, and the ways in which you can take the correct information, without missing out anything important. In this module, we will cover that ground a little more, reiterating the importance of how you handle telephone conversations, whilst also going into more detail about message taking.

      We will talk about the types of messages you may need to take, namely formal messages and informal messages, and explore the differences between them.       A person working as a receptionist who doesn't have good quality telephone skills will not last long in this line of work, purely because it is like a window cleaner who can't clean very well; the ability to communicate clearly and precisely is vital in reception work, and this is something which will probably be tested at interview, prior to being hired in a receptionist post. 

      Once you have taken a call and you have found out what it is the caller actually wants or needs, it may be that you need to pass the information onto a different department or a different person on your team, who can help them in a more specific way. If this is the case, you need to identify the type of message you are taking, and make sure you get as much detail as possible. On top of this, always inform the caller of what you are going to do next, e.g. pass the information on to someone who will either contact them by letter/email/call them back, but never make false promises. Always make sure the timescale you give to the caller for them to receive a response is a realistic one.

      The first telephone answering service started in 1923. Hello Inc. in Virginia, US, began under the name of Mrs Smith's Doctors Exchange. A bedridden Margaret Redmond Smith offered to answer calls for local doctors, and operated her business using an old French-style telephone mounted on a scissors-type extension near her bed.

    • In our last module, we talked at great length about telephone skills, and the importance of creating the correct impression via your tone of voice, and the language you use.

      We also briefly touched upon messaging taking, and the ways in which you can take the correct information, without missing out anything important.     • Message-taking forms such a hugely important part of a receptionist's day-to-day work, so it is proper and correct that we dedicate a whole module to this important process.
      By reading our last module, you will now be au-fait with the importance of telephone skills, as well as how to use your voice and language in order to make the right impression on the caller. We talked in our previous module about how you don't have the gift of body language to help you when discussing an issue over the telephone, as you would have with face to face discussions, and for that reason it is even more important to choose your words carefully, and to keep a clear eye on how your voice sounds, and how it is received by the caller. Picking the correct language and saying the right things is vital, without coming across as cold or uncaring. Whilst this can be a hard line to walk sometimes, with practice it will become second nature, as a professional telephone voice and knowing exactly what to say are two of the most important skills an effective receptionist should have.

A bedridden Margaret Redmond Smith offered to answer calls for local doctors, and operated her business using an old French-style telephone mounted on a scissors-type extension near her bed.
      A person working as a receptionist who doesn't have good quality telephone skills will not last long in this line of work, purely because it is like a window cleaner who can't clean very well; the ability to communicate clearly and precisely is vital in reception work, and this is something which will probably be tested at interview, prior to being hired in a receptionist post. 

      Once you have taken a call and you have found out what it is the caller actually wants or needs, it may be that you need to pass the information onto a different department or a different person on your team, who can help them in a more specific way. If this is the case, you need to identify the type of message you are taking, and make sure you get as much detail as possible. On top of this, always inform the caller of what you are going to do next, e.g. pass the information on to someone who will either contact them by letter/email/call them back, but never make false promises. Always make sure the timescale you give to the caller for them to receive a response is a realistic one.

      The first telephone answering service started in 1923. Hello Inc. in Virginia, US, began under the name of Mrs Smith's Doctors Exchange. A bedridden Margaret Redmond Smith offered to answer calls for local doctors, and operated her business using an old French-style telephone mounted on a scissors-type extension near her bed.

  • Lesson Summary

  • Here are the key points in this module:
    • As a receptionist, always be fresh, clean, and smell just as clean as you were when you got out of the shower that morning.
    • Ladies, again, hair needs to be clean, professional, and preferably not multi-coloured. Again, there is nothing wrong with hinting to your eclectic personality with a hair band or clip, but mute it down a little.
    • Nails should be clean, and if you wear nail polish, do not leave it to become chipped.
    • Of course, every organisation has slight differences, and that will affect the duties which a receptionist has in that particular business, but the general ethos of what a receptionist is, and what he or she does on a day-to-day basis, is pretty much the same.
    • The main types of reception jobs are: legal receptionists, medical receptionists, educational institute receptionists, tourism receptionists and general receptionists.
    • How you speak to someone is one of the most important first impressions they will be left with, along with the visual impression they have of you.
    • Always have good personal hygiene, your clothing should be smart and workplace appropriate, general grooming should be smart and not over the top and smiling as well as eye contact is vital.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Upon completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Define database.
    • Explain how to maintain a database in the most effective way.
    • Recall how to handle reservations effectively.
    • Differentiate between the duties of a receptionist and the duties of a secretary.
    • State the importance of a filing system.
    • Recall who is responsible for health and safety in the workplace.
    • Recognise the types of accidents that can occur in the workplace of a receptionist.

  • Working With Database

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • As part of your work as a receptionist, you may need to take many different types of bookings or reservations, which could span across a various range of different areas. 

    For example, you may take room bookings, or you may take appointment reservations; it all depends on the type of company you are working for as to what sort of bookings/reservations you deal with, but there are certain procedures and guidelines to follow regardless of what the booking is for.
  • On top of this, you will work closely with databases for many other different uses, and if you aren't too sure how to work a database, it's important to make sure you get some training on this beforehand. 

    Databases form a very important part of recordkeeping in the business world, and as a receptionist you will have access to many of these, as well as the duty of maintaining and adding to them. 

    In this module, we will discuss in much more detail regarding both of these subjects, giving you the knowledge and skills to know how to manage both databases and bookings/reservations, as well as a few examples on the kinds of subjects you can expect these to be on.

  • Administrative Procedures and Filing System

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • As a receptionist, you will be somewhat of a 'jack of all trades'. You will go through countless tasks and situations in the space of your working day, and a few of these tasks may fall outside of your usual remit. Of course, you should only ever undertake duties and tasks that are necessary for your job, and there may be a time when your duties overlap slightly with someone else in the organisation; for example, the duties of a receptionist, administrative assistant, or secretary sometimes do overlap to a certain degree.
  • There may be a grey area which falls in the middle of this, and it is important to know your boundaries in terms of responsibility. In this module, we will discuss the routine administrative tasks and procedures you will be expected to follow as a highly skilled and efficient receptionist, giving examples of those duties in a day-to-day setting. We will discuss a little more how duties can overlap in terms of job responsibility and title, and give you a general overview of how you can expect your daily duties to run. On top of this, we will explore filing systems, explaining and discussing why these are important, what to know in terms of confidentiality and Data Protection, discuss whether computerised or manual systems are better, and explore how to set up and maintain a system from the start. It is certainly worth pointing out that whilst we can give you an overview of the duties you can expect to go through as a receptionist, these aren't exhaustive examples, and you should also be aware that there will be bespoke duties which pertain to your particular role, depending on the type of organisation you are working for.

  • Security and Safety Issues at Work

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • One of the most important things in terms of general working life is to know that your working environment is safe, secure, and that you don't feel threatened or worried about your safety. Of course, any organisation worth its salt will have procedures in place to ensure the safety of their employees, and many have a no-tolerance policy in terms of verbal or even physical abuse on their employees by customers/clients/general members of the public. Because of this reason, you should never feel unsafe as part of your working life as a receptionist, and there should always be safety measures in place to help you feel that bit more reassured.
  • For example, a large organisation may have panic buttons installed, and a small organisation may do the same, and give you the necessary training to ensure that you know what to say and do. This is by no means put in place to scare you or make you feel uneasy, but it is something we need to talk about in any job role which deals with people, whether it is a receptionist, doctor, retail worker, or bar person. 

    Throughout this module, we will explore and discuss health and safety generally in the workplace, we will go through scenarios on what to do in certain situations, and we will talk in more depth about security and safety in terms of dealing with people and awkward situations. Of course, we discussed in length about difficult customers in one of our previous modules, and much of that knowledge should be put into place in this situation too.

  • One of the most important things in terms of general working life is to know that your working environment is safe, secure, and that you don't feel threatened or worried about your safety. Of course, any organisation worth its salt will have procedures in place to ensure the safety of their employees, and many have a no-tolerance policy in terms of verbal or even physical abuse on their employees by customers/clients/general members of the public. Because of this reason, you should never feel unsafe as part of your working life as a receptionist, and there should always be safety measures in place to help you feel that bit more reassured.
  • For example, a large organisation may have panic buttons installed, and a small organisation may do the same, and give you the necessary training to ensure that you know what to say and do. This is by no means put in place to scare you or make you feel uneasy, but it is something we need to talk about in any job role which deals with people, whether it is a receptionist, doctor, retail worker, or bar person. 

    Throughout this module, we will explore and discuss health and safety generally in the workplace, we will go through scenarios on what to do in certain situations, and we will talk in more depth about security and safety in terms of dealing with people and awkward situations. Of course, we discussed in length about difficult customers in one of our previous modules, and much of that knowledge should be put into place in this situation too.

  • Lesson Summary

  • Here are the key points in this module:
    • As part of your work as a receptionist, you may need to take many different types of bookings or reservations, which could span across a various range of different areas.
    • A database is basically known as a “collection of data', which means it is one place where a whole host of information is stored, in order to use it to collate statistics, reports, and graphs, and to answer questions.
    • If you are holding personal information on a member of staff or a customer, you need to ensure you comply with Data Protection guidelines, and this is enforceable by law.
    • Data protection means that any information held on a person must be kept up to date, only for the purpose required, and must only be accessed by those who need it for work reasons.
    • As a receptionist, you will be somewhat of a 'jack of all trades'.
    • When storing information on a computer, the data should be backed up regularly, encrypted, and should always be password-protected.
    • A manual filing system will basically take the form of a lockable filing cabinet, with labelled sections, which is fireproof, and the keys are only accessible to those who need them for their line of work.
    • A computerised filing system is a method to store information on a computer, through a database or spreadsheet.

  • Lesson Summary

  • Here are the key points in this module:
    • As part of your work as a receptionist, you may need to take many different types of bookings or reservations, which could span across a various range of different areas.
    • A database is basically known as a “collection of data', which means it is one place where a whole host of information is stored, in order to use it to collate statistics, reports, and graphs, and to answer questions.
    • If you are holding personal information on a member of staff or a customer, you need to ensure you comply with Data Protection guidelines, and this is enforceable by law.
    • Data protection means that any information held on a person must be kept up to date, only for the purpose required, and must only be accessed by those who need it for work reasons.
    • As a receptionist, you will be somewhat of a 'jack of all trades'.
    • When storing information on a computer, the data should be backed up regularly, encrypted, and should always be password-protected.
    • A manual filing system will basically take the form of a lockable filing cabinet, with labelled sections, which is fireproof, and the keys are only accessible to those who need them for their line of work.
    • A computerised filing system is a method to store information on a computer, through a database or spreadsheet.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Upon completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Define the concept of ‘confidentiality’.
    • Explain why confidentiality is important and how to maintain it.
    • Summarise how to arrange for a successful meeting.
    • Discuss minute-taking and how to do it.
    • Recall how to prioritise activities.
    • Differentiate between written and verbal communication.
    • Recall the types of informal and formal written communication.

  • Confidentiality

  • We have mentioned many times throughout this course to date about confidentiality; we have discussed why you need to adhere to it, and we have briefly touched upon ways you can ensure that confidentiality is always maintained. Because of the vital importance of this subject, this entire module will be dedicated to that huge issue beginning with C, and we will explore it in much more detail. By the end of this module, you will have a sure and detailed knowledge of how to maintain privacy and confidentiality at all times, to the point where it will simply become second nature in your role as a highly skilled and conscientious receptionist.

    • The actual definition of confidentiality is very difficult to pinpoint; it is one of those terms that we know what it is, but putting it into actual easy to understand words is very difficult. Put simply, confidentiality is the ways and means to ensure that sensitive information remains private, is not seen by those who don't require its vision, and to protect the identity and privacy of the person to whom the information pertains. In your role as receptionist, you will be privy to a whole host of confidential information, and it is probably the most important part of your job, other than creating that all important first impression we have mentioned countless times. You must ensure that any information you do have access to is kept private, secure, and that confidentiality is not breached. Every single person in the workplace has this responsibility. It is a common duty. However, as receptionist, you are going to be someone who has more access than most, i.e. personal files and telephone conversation content, etc.

    • Confidentiality is important for the following reasons:
      - If a customer/client/member of staff/caller/colleague knows that any information relating to them has been misused, i.e. it has been seen by those who don't really need to see it, then they will lose confidence in the company, which will result in loss of custom/business. Word will spread that information held is not kept secure, and again, more loss of business occurs.
      - There are circumstances whereby legal action can be taken, i.e. when Data Protection is not adhered to. Again, we will discuss this particular guideline in more detail later in this module, but Data Protection is a law enforceable situation, which has severe penalties when not adhered to.

Word will spread that information held is not kept secure, and again, more loss of business occurs.
      - There are circumstances whereby legal action can be taken, i.e. when Data Protection is not adhered to. Again, we will discuss this particular guideline in more detail later in this module, but Data Protection is a law enforceable situation, which has severe penalties when not adhered to.

      - Information could fall into the hands of a competitor, e.g. another business in the same line of
      work, which could mean customers are poached; this would again result in loss of business.
      These are just a few reasons why maintaining confidentiality is so vital within an organisation, and there are countless more besides. Any information that is communicated to you as receptionist should be dealt with in the correct manner, e.g. sensitively, discreetly, and never passed onto anyone else unless there is a work-based reason for it.

Any information that is communicated to you as receptionist should be dealt with in the correct manner, e.g. sensitively, discreetly, and never passed onto anyone else unless there is a work-based reason for it.

    • What Is Confidentiality?
      The actual definition of confidentiality is very difficult to pinpoint; it is one of those terms that we know what it is, but putting it into actual easy to understand words is very difficult. Put simply, confidentiality is the ways and means to ensure that sensitive information remains private, is not seen by those who don't require its vision, and to protect the identity and privacy of the person to whom the information pertains. In your role as receptionist, you will be privy to a whole host of confidential information, and it is probably the most important part of your job, other than creating that all important first impression we have mentioned countless times. You must ensure that any information you do have access to is kept private, secure, and that confidentiality is not breached. Every single person in the workplace has this responsibility. It is a common duty. However, as receptionist, you are going to be someone who has more access than most, i.e. personal files and telephone conversation content, etc.
      The actual definition of confidentiality is very difficult to pinpoint; it is one of those terms that we know what it is, but putting it into actual easy to understand words is very difficult. Put simply, confidentiality is the ways and means to ensure that sensitive information remains private, is not seen by those who don't require its vision, and to protect the identity and privacy of the person to whom the information pertains. In your role as receptionist, you will be privy to a whole host of confidential information, and it is probably the most important part of your job, other than creating that all important first impression we have mentioned countless times.       Customer ID
      Customer Name
    • So, Why Is Confidentiality Important?
      Again, this is one of those subjects that is difficult to put into words. Confidentiality is not just important - it is vital. There is no excuse for information falling into the wrong hands, and if you are found liable for this, there is the possibility that you will be subject to severe disciplinary procedures, depending on the policies of your particular workplace and the circumstances around the incident. We will discuss in a little more detail shortly about the consequences of breaching confidentiality.
      Again, this is one of those subjects that is difficult to put into words. Confidentiality is not just important - it is vital. There is no excuse for information falling into the wrong hands, and if you are found liable for this, there is the possibility that you will be subject to severe disciplinary procedures, depending on the policies of your particular workplace and the circumstances around the incident. We will discuss in a little more detail shortly about the consequences of breaching confidentiality.
      Customer ID
      Customer Name
    • Importance of Confidentiality
      Confidentiality is important for the following reasons:
      - If a customer/client/member of staff/caller/colleague knows that any information relating to them has been misused, i.e. it has been seen by those who don't really need to see it, then they will lose confidence in the company, which will result in loss of custom/business. Word will spread that information held is not kept secure, and again, more loss of business occurs.
      - There are circumstances whereby legal action can be taken, i.e. when Data Protection is not adhered to. Again, we will discuss this particular guideline in more detail later in this module, but Data Protection is a law enforceable situation, which has severe penalties when not adhered to.
      Confidentiality is important for the following reasons:
      - If a customer/client/member of staff/caller/colleague knows that any information relating to them has been misused, i.e. it has been seen by those who don't really need to see it, then they will lose confidence in the company, which will result in loss of custom/business.       Customer ID
      Customer Name
    • Other Importance of Confidentiality
      - In severe cases, information could be leaked to the press, which would have potentially catastrophic consequences for a business, potentially resulting in legal action, depending on what the information was pertaining to.
      - Information could fall into the hands of a competitor, e.g. another business in the same line of
      work, which could mean customers are poached; this would again result in loss of business.
      These are just a few reasons why maintaining confidentiality is so vital within an organisation, and there are countless more besides. Any information that is communicated to you as receptionist should be dealt with in the correct manner, e.g. sensitively, discreetly, and never passed onto anyone else unless there is a work-based reason for it.

There is no excuse for information falling into the wrong hands, and if you are found liable for this, there is the possibility that you will be subject to severe disciplinary procedures, depending on the policies of your particular workplace and the circumstances around the incident. We will discuss in a little more detail shortly about the consequences of breaching confidentiality.

    • Importance of Confidentiality
      Confidentiality is important for the following reasons:
      - If a customer/client/member of staff/caller/colleague knows that any information relating to them has been misused, i.e. it has been seen by those who don't really need to see it, then they will lose confidence in the company, which will result in loss of custom/business. Word will spread that information held is not kept secure, and again, more loss of business occurs.
      - There are circumstances whereby legal action can be taken, i.e. when Data Protection is not adhered to. Again, we will discuss this particular guideline in more detail later in this module, but Data Protection is a law enforceable situation, which has severe penalties when not adhered to.
      Confidentiality is important for the following reasons:
      - If a customer/client/member of staff/caller/colleague knows that any information relating to them has been misused, i.e. it has been seen by those who don't really need to see it, then they will lose confidence in the company, which will result in loss of custom/business. Word will spread that information held is not kept secure, and again, more loss of business occurs.
      - There are circumstances whereby legal action can be taken, i.e. when Data Protection is not adhered to. Again, we will discuss this particular guideline in more detail later in this module, but Data Protection is a law enforceable situation, which has severe penalties when not adhered to.
      Customer ID
      Customer Name
    • Other Importance of Confidentiality
      - In severe cases, information could be leaked to the press, which would have potentially catastrophic consequences for a business, potentially resulting in legal action, depending on what the information was pertaining to.
      - Information could fall into the hands of a competitor, e.g. another business in the same line of
      work, which could mean customers are poached; this would again result in loss of business.
      These are just a few reasons why maintaining confidentiality is so vital within an organisation, and there are countless more besides. Any information that is communicated to you as receptionist should be dealt with in the correct manner, e.g. sensitively, discreetly, and never passed onto anyone else unless there is a work-based reason for it.

      We will discuss in detail regarding what to do in order to arrange a meeting or event, the kinds of arrangements you may need to make, how to make them, and we will talk about minute- taking.     • What Makes a Successful Meeting?
      The best answer to that question is a simple one - plenty of thought and attention to detail. A successful meeting is in the running of it, i.e. the correct equipment is made available, the room isn't double booked or booked for too short a time, the refreshments are available and arrive at the correct time, and attendees are shown to the venue when they arrive, without having to find it and potentially get lost in a large building they are not familiar with.
      Of course, what is discussed and decided upon during the meeting decides whether it is successful or not in terms of business, but from your point of view, and the point of view of the receptionist and administrative team, how the meeting runs is the most important thing to take into account.

    • New Tab
    • Time Management
    • What Are Organisational Skills?
    • How Can You Prioritise?
    • Enter your text here..

    • Enter your text here..
      A highly skilled, effective, and efficient receptionist understands the concept of time management and knows how to use it to his or her gain. On top of this, a highly-skilled, effective, and efficient receptionist also knows how to prioritise every single task on his or her to do list, as well as anything else which is thrown at them.
      Sounds impossible?
      Not at all!
      With time you will become a master at managing your time, prioritising your workload, and dealing with whatever the day decides to throw at you, all without breaking a sweat. In this module, we will discuss exactly what organisational skills are, why a receptionist needs them, what prioritising is, as well as giving you a few scenarios to help you understand how it all works in practice. Time management will also be discussed in detail, to help you understand how you can make it work for you, effectively inventing extra hours in your working day! We will end our module by giving you a reiteration and run down on those personality skills which every effective receptionist should have.
      Customer ID
      Customer Name
    • Enter your text here..
      Organisational skills are almost like something you can't put into words, they just are, but they can be lumped under an umbrella of skills which allow you to go through your day-to-day working life, without major problems, or running out of time on a regular basis. Of course, everyone has those days when there simply aren't enough hours in the day, but if you are skilled receptionist with top-class organisational skills, you shouldn't have these days on a too regular basis. Prior to popular knowledge, organisational skills can be learnt - they are not only something you are born with.

      Yes, many people are just organised types, they write to-do lists and they never miss a thing, and if that is you, congratulations, because you are well-equipped for life as a receptionist without even having to learn these important life skills! If you're not that type of person, the good news is that with the right knowledge and a little practice, you can easily train yourself to be that way, and once you become more relaxed and knowledgeable in your role, this will come as second nature to you. One of the key facets to a well-rounded set of organisational skills is the ability to effectively prioritise your duties into order of importance.
      Customer ID
      Customer Name
    • Prioritising is the ability to put your duties, as we have just mentioned, into the order of importance, and to carry them out in the correct way, to enable deadlines to be met at all times.

      Prioritising can be difficult at times, especially if you have a few duties that fall into the same kind of remit, but then you have to make a decision and work to that priority. Moving on to how you can actually prioritise, it's basically a little bit of common sense, with a little extra job knowledge thrown in for good measure. We'll look at a few scenarios shortly to help you understand prioritising a little more, and let you work out a few yourself. The bottom line is that prioritising is so very important in any administrative-based job, because it means you are working to deadlines effectively.

      If you constantly miss deadlines, this not only gives a very negative impression of you as a receptionist, but also the organisation overall when it impacts outside forces, which can have much further-reaching effects too, such as loss of custom.

      Meeting deadlines is easy when you can prioritise your tasks, however we won't lie, sometimes unavoidable situations happen, and we do sometimes miss a deadline. If this does occur, in the time leading up to the problem, discuss with your line manager about what you can see happening, the reasons for it, and explore any ways you can put a contingency plan into place, e.g. someone else helping out to complete the task on time. Team work with an organisation like this is key.

    • How Can You Prioritise?
      Prioritising is the ability to put your duties, as we have just mentioned, into the order of importance, and to carry them out in the correct way, to enable deadlines to be met at all times.

      Prioritising can be difficult at times, especially if you have a few duties that fall into the same kind of remit, but then you have to make a decision and work to that priority. Moving on to how you can actually prioritise, it's basically a little bit of common sense, with a little extra job knowledge thrown in for good measure. We'll look at a few scenarios shortly to help you understand prioritising a little more, and let you work out a few yourself. The bottom line is that prioritising is so very important in any administrative-based job, because it means you are working to deadlines effectively.

      If you constantly miss deadlines, this not only gives a very negative impression of you as a receptionist, but also the organisation overall when it impacts outside forces, which can have much further-reaching effects too, such as loss of custom.

      Meeting deadlines is easy when you can prioritise your tasks, however we won't lie, sometimes unavoidable situations happen, and we do sometimes miss a deadline. If this does occur, in the time leading up to the problem, discuss with your line manager about what you can see happening, the reasons for it, and explore any ways you can put a contingency plan into place, e.g. someone else helping out to complete the task on time. Team work with an organisation like this is key.

    • How Can You Prioritise?
      Prioritising is the ability to put your duties, as we have just mentioned, into the order of importance, and to carry them out in the correct way, to enable deadlines to be met at all times.

      Prioritising can be difficult at times, especially if you have a few duties that fall into the same kind of remit, but then you have to make a decision and work to that priority. Moving on to how you can actually prioritise, it's basically a little bit of common sense, with a little extra job knowledge thrown in for good measure. We'll look at a few scenarios shortly to help you understand prioritising a little more, and let you work out a few yourself. The bottom line is that prioritising is so very important in any administrative-based job, because it means you are working to deadlines effectively.

      If you constantly miss deadlines, this not only gives a very negative impression of you as a receptionist, but also the organisation overall when it impacts outside forces, which can have much further-reaching effects too, such as loss of custom.

      Meeting deadlines is easy when you can prioritise your tasks, however we won't lie, sometimes unavoidable situations happen, and we do sometimes miss a deadline. If this does occur, in the time leading up to the problem, discuss with your line manager about what you can see happening, the reasons for it, and explore any ways you can put a contingency plan into place, e.g. someone else helping out to complete the task on time. Team work with an organisation like this is key.

      With time you will become a master at managing your time, prioritising your workload, and dealing with whatever the day decides to throw at you, all without breaking a sweat. In this module, we will discuss exactly what organisational skills are, why a receptionist needs them, what prioritising is, as well as giving you a few scenarios to help you understand how it all works in practice. Time management will also be discussed in detail, to help you understand how you can make it work for you, effectively inventing extra hours in your working day! We will end our module by giving you a reiteration and run down on those personality skills which every effective receptionist should have.
      A highly skilled, effective, and efficient receptionist understands the concept of time management and knows how to use it to his or her gain. On top of this, a highly-skilled, effective, and efficient receptionist also knows how to prioritise every single task on his or her to do list, as well as anything else which is thrown at them.

    • What Are Organisational Skills?
      Organisational skills are almost like something you can't put into words, they just are, but they can be lumped under an umbrella of skills which allow you to go through your day-to-day working life, without major problems, or running out of time on a regular basis. Of course, everyone has those days when there simply aren't enough hours in the day, but if you are skilled receptionist with top-class organisational skills, you shouldn't have these days on a too regular basis. Prior to popular knowledge, organisational skills can be learnt - they are not only something you are born with.

      Yes, many people are just organised types, they write to-do lists and they never miss a thing, and if that is you, congratulations, because you are well-equipped for life as a receptionist without even having to learn these important life skills! If you're not that type of person, the good news is that with the right knowledge and a little practice, you can easily train yourself to be that way, and once you become more relaxed and knowledgeable in your role, this will come as second nature to you. One of the key facets to a well-rounded set of organisational skills is the ability to effectively prioritise your duties into order of importance.

    • How Can You Prioritise?
      Prioritising is the ability to put your duties, as we have just mentioned, into the order of importance, and to carry them out in the correct way, to enable deadlines to be met at all times.

      Prioritising can be difficult at times, especially if you have a few duties that fall into the same kind of remit, but then you have to make a decision and work to that priority. Moving on to how you can actually prioritise, it's basically a little bit of common sense, with a little extra job knowledge thrown in for good measure. We'll look at a few scenarios shortly to help you understand prioritising a little more, and let you work out a few yourself. The bottom line is that prioritising is so very important in any administrative-based job, because it means you are working to deadlines effectively.

      If you constantly miss deadlines, this not only gives a very negative impression of you as a receptionist, but also the organisation overall when it impacts outside forces, which can have much further-reaching effects too, such as loss of custom.

      Meeting deadlines is easy when you can prioritise your tasks, however we won't lie, sometimes unavoidable situations happen, and we do sometimes miss a deadline. If this does occur, in the time leading up to the problem, discuss with your line manager about what you can see happening, the reasons for it, and explore any ways you can put a contingency plan into place, e.g. someone else helping out to complete the task on time. Team work with an organisation like this is key.

  • Communication

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Whether you work for a large organisation or a small one, there will be times when information needs to be communicated in a non-verbal way. This could be a formal method or it could be something much more informal, yet whatever form this takes, it is important to understand the way written communication should be presented, the content which should be held within it, how to send written communication, and how to store it. Of course, we should also mention confidentiality in this too, to ensure that any information communicated does not fall into the wrong hands. Throughout this module, we will discuss the different types of written communication you may come into contact with, whether you need to produce them yourself, receive them, or distribute them.
  • Certain organisations may ask their receptionist to compile memos, reply to correspondence from outside agencies, or put together newsletters, for example. It is important to know how to set these out, to comply with not only organisational rules, but also the general administrative layout of such documentation. We should obviously point out that every organisation will be different in terms of how they like their written correspondence to be laid out, and you must always follow company policy in terms of this. We can't go through every possibility here - there simply isn't the room - but we can give you a guideline on how such correspondence is laid out generally speaking, for you to tweak as you need to, according to company guidelines.

  • Lesson Summary

  • Here are the key points in this module:
    • Confidentiality is the way and means to ensure that sensitive information remains private and is not seen by those who don't require its vision, and protects the identity and privacy of the person to whom the information pertains.
    • You must ensure that any information you do have access to is kept private, and secure and that confidentiality is not breached.
    • There is no excuse for information falling into the wrong hands, and if you are found liable for this, there is the possibility that you will be subject to severe disciplinary procedures, depending on the policies of your particular workplace and the circumstances around the incident.
    • The Data Protection Act is something that everyone who handles data has to take into account and adhere to strictly.
    • In a large organisation, there will be several meetings going on throughout the space of a day, let alone a week, and it may be your responsibility as receptionist to make arrangements, to ensure the smooth running of the event itself.
    • Minute-taking is the process of recording what is said and the actions decided upon during the course of the meeting.
    • Minutes can be shown in the form of bullet points, or they can be in properly structured paragraphs, in a more formal manner.

  • Lesson Summary

  • Here are the key points in this module:
    • Confidentiality is the way and means to ensure that sensitive information remains private and is not seen by those who don't require its vision, and protects the identity and privacy of the person to whom the information pertains.
    • You must ensure that any information you do have access to is kept private, and secure and that confidentiality is not breached.
    • There is no excuse for information falling into the wrong hands, and if you are found liable for this, there is the possibility that you will be subject to severe disciplinary procedures, depending on the policies of your particular workplace and the circumstances around the incident.
    • The Data Protection Act is something that everyone who handles data has to take into account and adhere to strictly.
    • In a large organisation, there will be several meetings going on throughout the space of a day, let alone a week, and it may be your responsibility as receptionist to make arrangements, to ensure the smooth running of the event itself.
    • Minute-taking is the process of recording what is said and the actions decided upon during the course of the meeting.
    • Minutes can be shown in the form of bullet points, or they can be in properly structured paragraphs, in a more formal manner.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Upon completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Discuss the crucial part that technology plays in administrative work.
    • Identify the technology and software packages that are useful to a receptionist.
    • Explain the importance of teamwork and how it relates to the role of a receptionist.
    • Outline the attributes of a good team leader.
    • Summarise how to make a reception area look welcoming and professional.
    • Recall the potential future career paths a receptionist can undertake.

  • The Role of Technology in Reception Work

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The world has seemingly been taken over by technology of some kind, don't you find? Whether you're ordering your groceries online, checking your Facebook newsfeed, watching films over Netflix, or booking a holiday on your iPad, everything we do these days is based on the Internet, or done through some technological gadget which we can't imagine living without. Work-life is the same in many ways, and more and more tasks are done in a computerised manner, when they used to be done in a more manual way.
  • For instance, once upon a time you had a paper diary to fill in someone's work commitments, when booking meetings, etc.; nowadays, you log onto a database which several people have access to and simply press a few keys to book a slot.

    Whether you find it easy to use technology or not, there is no denying that having a go and learning is the only way to ensure that you stay up to date and ahead of the game. When working on a reception desk, you will deal with a variety of different types of technology, and we will go over and discuss these in more detail throughout this module.

    It is worth mentioning however, if you do feel a little anxious about technology, or you're unsure of how to use something, it is always best to speak to your manager to access training - once you know how to do something, the fear is taken away, and you will be tapping away on that computer keyboard before you know it!

    It is worth mentioning however, if you do feel a little anxious about technology, or you're unsure of how to use something, it is always best to speak to your manager to access training - once you know how to do something, the fear is taken away, and you will be tapping away on that computer keyboard before you know it!

  • Team Work and Its Importance

    • New Tab
      Enter your text here..
      Enter your text here..
    • Importance of Team Work
      Enter your text here..
      In any role, we have to consider the importance of teamwork.
      Why?
      Because working as a team is vitally important to ensuring every task is done in the correct timescale, and to the correct standard. Look at it this way - if you can't complete a task and you don't have team members to ask for help, what happens? You fail, that's what! In this module, we will explore in more detail about team work, we will discuss what it is, how it works within a receptionist role, and we will talk about what makes a good team. On top of this, we will also explore what happens if you have a problem with a member of your team; this is an awkward situation at the best of times, but understanding how to handle it with grace and in the correct manner overall, is vital to ensuring that working relationships aren't damaged, as well as ensuring all your work is completed successfully. First things first, however; let's talk about what team work actually is.
    • What Is Team Work?
      Enter your text here..
      Team work is basically the process of working with other people towards a common aim. That's probably the simplest way to put it. Of course, team work is much more complex in practice, but generally speaking, the definition of the term means that you are all focused on completing the same thing, for the same reason.

      Nobody is more important than anyone else within a team, hence the well-documented saying - There is no 'I' in team.

      There are many situations whereby teamwork is required, and although you may be in a role which is a little individually based, e.g. you work in an office alone, the whole administrative section is strictly speaking a team. You don't have to be interchangeable to be a team, i.e. you don't have to be trained up in every single person's job, but the ability to slot into general administrative roles with ease is always a plus.
    • Instance of Team Work
      Enter your text here..
      For instance
      The departmental secretary may be off sick, and as an administrative team as a whole, you may be asked to do different parts of his or her job, to tide things over until he or she returns.

      You may be asked to take the telephone calls, someone else may be asked to type up the reports, and another member of staff may be asked to open and distribute the mail for that particular role. Teamwork is a little like pulling together in adverse situations in order to help continue the service running smoothly for the good of the customers/clients.
      There are many other situations whereby team work may be required.
    • Scenario 1
      A large project is designated to the fashion department within a magazine, and it is imperative that it is completed by the 1st of the month. Your particular duty is running a little behind, and if you don't complete your part of the project, the whole thing will fail.
      Solution: Speak to your manager and explain the situation, and another member of the team can be pulled into your part of the project to help you complete it on time. This means that everyone is happy because the job is done, and you will have a sense of achievement overall.
      Enter your text here..
    • Scenario 2
      A new member of staff has started within the organisation and she isn't so familiar with the company database. She has had training, but she is struggling to pick up a few different prompts within the software, which means she is generally slow when working on tasks relating to it.
      Enter your text here..
    • Scenario 3
      A member of staff is off sick and several tasks from the previous day have been left unfinished. As the member of staff may be back at work the following day, it is not cost-effective to bring in an agency worker.
      Solution: There are certain general administrative tasks that are common in many different roles, and as a team you can work to ensure these are finished, keeping the job ticking over until the member of staff returns from sickness. Team work isn't rocket science, and much of it is to do with pulling together and working with one aim in mind.
      Enter your text here..

You fail, that's what! In this module, we will explore in more detail about team work, we will discuss what it is, how it works within a receptionist role, and we will talk about what makes a good team. On top of this, we will also explore what happens if you have a problem with a member of your team; this is an awkward situation at the best of times, but understanding how to handle it with grace and in the correct manner overall, is vital to ensuring that working relationships aren't damaged, as well as ensuring all your work is completed successfully. First things first, however; let's talk about what team work actually is.
    • What Is Team Work?
      Enter your text here..
      Team work is basically the process of working with other people towards a common aim. That's probably the simplest way to put it. Of course, team work is much more complex in practice, but generally speaking, the definition of the term means that you are all focused on completing the same thing, for the same reason.

      Nobody is more important than anyone else within a team, hence the well-documented saying - There is no 'I' in team.

      There are many situations whereby teamwork is required, and although you may be in a role which is a little individually based, e.g. you work in an office alone, the whole administrative section is strictly speaking a team. You don't have to be interchangeable to be a team, i.e. you don't have to be trained up in every single person's job, but the ability to slot into general administrative roles with ease is always a plus.
    • Instance of Team Work
      Enter your text here..
      For instance
      The departmental secretary may be off sick, and as an administrative team as a whole, you may be asked to do different parts of his or her job, to tide things over until he or she returns.

      You may be asked to take the telephone calls, someone else may be asked to type up the reports, and another member of staff may be asked to open and distribute the mail for that particular role. Teamwork is a little like pulling together in adverse situations in order to help continue the service running smoothly for the good of the customers/clients.
      There are many other situations whereby team work may be required.
    • Scenario 1
      A large project is designated to the fashion department within a magazine, and it is imperative that it is completed by the 1st of the month. Your particular duty is running a little behind, and if you don't complete your part of the project, the whole thing will fail.
      Solution: Speak to your manager and explain the situation, and another member of the team can be pulled into your part of the project to help you complete it on time. This means that everyone is happy because the job is done, and you will have a sense of achievement overall.
      Enter your text here..
    • Scenario 2
      A new member of staff has started within the organisation and she isn't so familiar with the company database. She has had training, but she is struggling to pick up a few different prompts within the software, which means she is generally slow when working on tasks relating to it.
      Enter your text here..
    • Scenario 3
      A member of staff is off sick and several tasks from the previous day have been left unfinished. As the member of staff may be back at work the following day, it is not cost-effective to bring in an agency worker.
      Solution: There are certain general administrative tasks that are common in many different roles, and as a team you can work to ensure these are finished, keeping the job ticking over until the member of staff returns from sickness. Team work isn't rocket science, and much of it is to do with pulling together and working with one aim in mind.
      Enter your text here..

    • We have talked at length in our previous modules about the vital importance of a good first impression, i.e. using your body language, voice, language, and appearance to create the correct first view of your organisation as a whole.

      We know that if you are untidy in appearance, you're sat at the reception desk yawning, and you simply don't seem bothered about helping anyone, this is not going to give the best first impression to anyone who walks through the doors of your building, whether you go on to give them first class customer service or not; that first impression will stick with them for life!

      The same can be said about telephone conversations, and we have talked about how you can use your voice and language to give the impression that you care about what is being said to you, without the aid of body language. Now, equally important is the appearance of the reception area overall.

      In this module, we will talk about why you need to keep your reception area tidy and neat, in terms of appearance and confidentiality, and we will discuss just how you can do this, as well as maintenance tips to make all the difference.
      Enter your text here..

    • Enter your text here..
      Okay, picture the scene. You walk into a building and the first thing you see is piles of untidy magazines on a table, a dead pot plant, empty coffee cups on the waiting area tables, and a reception desk which is piled high with box files and random junk, which doesn't seem to serve any real purpose.
      What do you think about it?
      Of course, you will have one of the following, or maybe all of, the following thoughts:
      1. Is this receptionist at all bothered about the reception area, and therefore is he or she going to be bothered about helping me?
      2. This doesn't look very professional.
      3. Is this clean? Can I catch something?
      4. Oh my god, my OCD has gone into meltdown.

    • Put simply, this is the ultimate in bad first impressions. You could actually cause a visitor an injury by keeping an untidy reception area, because they could trip over something, slip on a spillage that you didn't realise was there, knock something over and then bang their head on the way back up, the list goes on.

      You don't want your visitors to be leaving the building nursing and injury, you want them to be leaving the building having had their needs met! Basically, a first impression is made by the way you look yourself, the way you deal with the person and the people around you, and the way your reception area appears too.

      Nobody is going to have much confidence in an organisation which can't even keep their reception area, the first port of call for anyone entering the building, tidy at the very least.     • Possible Outcomes From an Untidy Work Area
      Put simply, this is the ultimate in bad first impressions. You could actually cause a visitor an injury by keeping an untidy reception area, because they could trip over something, slip on a spillage that you didn't realise was there, knock something over and then bang their head on the way back up, the list goes on.

      You don't want your visitors to be leaving the building nursing and injury, you want them to be leaving the building having had their needs met! Basically, a first impression is made by the way you look yourself, the way you deal with the person and the people around you, and the way your reception area appears too.

      Nobody is going to have much confidence in an organisation which can't even keep their reception area, the first port of call for anyone entering the building, tidy at the very least. It's not hard to keep things tidy and clean, and if you keep on top of it every day, e.g. tidying at regular intervals, this shouldn't pose too much of an issue.

    • Possible Outcomes From an Untidy Work Area
      Put simply, this is the ultimate in bad first impressions. You could actually cause a visitor an injury by keeping an untidy reception area, because they could trip over something, slip on a spillage that you didn't realise was there, knock something over and then bang their head on the way back up, the list goes on.

      You don't want your visitors to be leaving the building nursing and injury, you want them to be leaving the building having had their needs met! Basically, a first impression is made by the way you look yourself, the way you deal with the person and the people around you, and the way your reception area appears too.

      Nobody is going to have much confidence in an organisation which can't even keep their reception area, the first port of call for anyone entering the building, tidy at the very least. It's not hard to keep things tidy and clean, and if you keep on top of it every day, e.g. tidying at regular intervals, this shouldn't pose too much of an issue.

    • Why the Appearance of the Reception Area Is Just As Important as Personal Appearance
      Okay, picture the scene. You walk into a building and the first thing you see is piles of untidy magazines on a table, a dead pot plant, empty coffee cups on the waiting area tables, and a reception desk which is piled high with box files and random junk, which doesn't seem to serve any real purpose.
      What do you think about it?
      Of course, you will have one of the following, or maybe all of, the following thoughts:
      1. Is this receptionist at all bothered about the reception area, and therefore is he or she going to be bothered about helping me?
      2. This doesn't look very professional.
      3. Is this clean? Can I catch something?
      4. Oh my god, my OCD has gone into meltdown.
