    • Possible Outcomes From an Untidy Work Area
      Put simply, this is the ultimate in bad first impressions. You could actually cause a visitor an injury by keeping an untidy reception area, because they could trip over something, slip on a spillage that you didn't realise was there, knock something over and then bang their head on the way back up, the list goes on.

      You don't want your visitors to be leaving the building nursing and injury, you want them to be leaving the building having had their needs met! Basically, a first impression is made by the way you look yourself, the way you deal with the person and the people around you, and the way your reception area appears too.

      Nobody is going to have much confidence in an organisation which can't even keep their reception area, the first port of call for anyone entering the building, tidy at the very least. It's not hard to keep things tidy and clean, and if you keep on top of it every day, e.g. tidying at regular intervals, this shouldn't pose too much of an issue.

    • Types of Receptionist Roles You Can Undertake

    • As we move towards the end of our course, you should now have a broader overview in your mind of what makes a top receptionist, as well as being armed with plentiful information to help give you that slight extra edge in terms of performance. In this particular module, we will talk about what happens next, i.e. your career progression options should you choose to move onwards and upwards from your role as receptionist.

      Of course, maybe you're perfectly happy in your role, and that's fine, but if you are using your receptionist role as a stepping stone to bigger things, there are certainly plentiful options out there and roads you can take. Working as a receptionist is a wonderful way to develop your communication and organisation skills, because in order to become the best out there, you need to be at the top of your game in terms of dealing with people, problems, and thinking on your feet. There is not a receptionist out there who isn't highly skilled in these areas. With all of this in mind, what can you do in the future if you want to move on from your current role?
      As we move towards the end of our course, you should now have a broader overview in your mind of what makes a top receptionist, as well as being armed with plentiful information to help give you that slight extra edge in terms of performance. In this particular module, we will talk about what happens next, i.e. your career progression options should you choose to move onwards and upwards from your role as receptionist.

Working as a receptionist is a wonderful way to develop your communication and organisation skills, because in order to become the best out there, you need to be at the top of your game in terms of dealing with people, problems, and thinking on your feet. There is not a receptionist out there who isn't highly skilled in these areas. With all of this in mind, what can you do in the future if you want to move on from your current role?
    • If you do have aspirations to develop your career, then working as a receptionist is a wonderful starting point. You will learn and develop countless skills which are very transferable, as well as being very valuable in general daily life. We will discuss the skills you will learn in a little more detail in our next section, however this particular section will talk about where you can go, if you choose to move forwards. Again, we will reiterate, if you choose not to progress on from your role as receptionist, not a problem! A receptionist role is an important and skilled job in its own right, and many people choose to move from organisation to organisation within this role, in a sideways step, or choose to stay with the same organisation and earn themselves extra responsibilities to go alongside it.
      Certain reception roles are more likely to offer you routes to take in the future, such as:
      - Medical receptionist.
      - Legal receptionist.
      - Receptionist with a large public organisation, such as the NHS or a local council, for example.
      Basically, any reception role which has room for manoeuvre, e.g. there is room within the organisation to move, is a good place to start.

      Certain reception roles are more likely to offer you routes to take in the future, such as:
      - Medical receptionist.
      - Legal receptionist.
      - Receptionist with a large public organisation, such as the NHS or a local council, for example.
      Basically, any reception role which has room for manoeuvre, e.g. there is room within the organisation to move, is a good place to start.
    • If you start your career path within a large organisation, you have time and opportunities to move; however, that doesn't mean you can't move from organisation to organisation and do the same thing.
      These are some of the roads you can take, should you wish to progress:
      - Medical secretary.
      - Legal secretary.
      - School secretary.
      - Court transcriber
      - Management roles (with extra training).
      - Head of administrative departments.
      - Head receptionist (with supervisory responsibility over a team of receptionists).
      - Customer service roles.
      - Complaints advisor.
      These are some of the roles you can move into over time, when working as a receptionist.

    • Types of Receptionist Roles You Can Undertake
      If you do have aspirations to develop your career, then working as a receptionist is a wonderful starting point. You will learn and develop countless skills which are very transferable, as well as being very valuable in general daily life. We will discuss the skills you will learn in a little more detail in our next section, however this particular section will talk about where you can go, if you choose to move forwards. Again, we will reiterate, if you choose not to progress on from your role as receptionist, not a problem! A receptionist role is an important and skilled job in its own right, and many people choose to move from organisation to organisation within this role, in a sideways step, or choose to stay with the same organisation and earn themselves extra responsibilities to go alongside it.
      Certain reception roles are more likely to offer you routes to take in the future, such as:
      - Medical receptionist.
      - Legal receptionist.
      - Receptionist with a large public organisation, such as the NHS or a local council, for example.
      Basically, any reception role which has room for manoeuvre, e.g. there is room within the organisation to move, is a good place to start.

  • Promotion from being a receptionist
    ×

    Promotion to Other Roles as a Receptionist

    We should mention again that there are many more roles you could potentially move into, and it depends on the kind of organisation you are working for. Any large organisation will be keen to recruit to new posts from current workers, mainly because they already know the ropes in terms of how the organisation works, from the mail system, to where everything is, who people are, and the general day to day running of the organisation as a whole. This means that there are many chances to move within the organisation across your working life, using each job as a stepping stone to something greater, if you so wish.

A receptionist role is an important and skilled job in its own right, and many people choose to move from organisation to organisation within this role, in a sideways step, or choose to stay with the same organisation and earn themselves extra responsibilities to go alongside it.

      - Medical receptionist.
      - Legal receptionist.
      - Receptionist with a large public organisation, such as the NHS or a local council, for example.

  • Promotion from being a receptionist
    ×

    Promotion to Other Roles as a Receptionist

    We should mention again that there are many more roles you could potentially move into, and it depends on the kind of organisation you are working for. Any large organisation will be keen to recruit to new posts from current workers, mainly because they already know the ropes in terms of how the organisation works, from the mail system, to where everything is, who people are, and the general day to day running of the organisation as a whole. This means that there are many chances to move within the organisation across your working life, using each job as a stepping stone to something greater, if you so wish.

  • Promotion from being a receptionist
    ×

    Promotion to Other Roles as a Receptionist

    We should mention again that there are many more roles you could potentially move into, and it depends on the kind of organisation you are working for. Any large organisation will be keen to recruit to new posts from current workers, mainly because they already know the ropes in terms of how the organisation works, from the mail system, to where everything is, who people are, and the general day to day running of the organisation as a whole. This means that there are many chances to move within the organisation across your working life, using each job as a stepping stone to something greater, if you so wish.

      Despite the fact, there will always be slight differences between receptionist roles, from company to company, the basis of the role itself will always be the same, and if you can master the foundations, you are on your way to being the best in the business.

Using your voice, language, and body language is one of the key ways to create a positive impression, ensuring repeat business in the future, word of mouth business, and also pleasing the visitor/caller at the same time.
      We will mention that big C word once more here - Confidentiality.

      Aside from creating that first impression and catering to your visitors and callers' needs, you have a huge responsibility in terms of confidentiality too. You will be privy to sensitive and private information throughout the course of your job, and it is imperative that you always exercise the measures to maintain confidentiality. Don't worry if this all sounds rather worrying at first, because the actual methods are quite often common sense, as we have discussed, and they will become second nature to you very soon after beginning your receptionist role.

    • The Key Skills and Attributes a Top Receptionist Should Have
      To give you a quick reference point, if ever you need to check back over the course during your time working as a receptionist, this is a summary of the top skills, personality traits, and attributes which an effectively and highly skilled receptionist should have.

      Of course, everyone is different, and it may be that you lack in one area but make up for it in others. Certain skills are more important than other ones, that's for sure, but communication and organisation are certainly two of the most important in this line of work!

    • Reiteration on What Reception Work Is, in Its Most Basic Form
      For Example

      Well turned out, well-kept, professional in appearance, and neat and tidy, but also keeping the reception area in the same way. Of course, your general demeanour and the way you speak to people is also key. Using your voice, language, and body language is one of the key ways to create a positive impression, ensuring repeat business in the future, word of mouth business, and also pleasing the visitor/caller at the same time.
      We will mention that big C word once more here - Confidentiality.

      Aside from creating that first impression and catering to your visitors and callers' needs, you have a huge responsibility in terms of confidentiality too. You will be privy to sensitive and private information throughout the course of your job, and it is imperative that you always exercise the measures to maintain confidentiality. Don't worry if this all sounds rather worrying at first, because the actual methods are quite often common sense, as we have discussed, and they will become second nature to you very soon after beginning your receptionist role.

    • The Key Skills and Attributes a Top Receptionist Should Have
      To give you a quick reference point, if ever you need to check back over the course during your time working as a receptionist, this is a summary of the top skills, personality traits, and attributes which an effectively and highly skilled receptionist should have.

      Of course, everyone is different, and it may be that you lack in one area but make up for it in others. Certain skills are more important than other ones, that's for sure, but communication and organisation are certainly two of the most important in this line of work!

    • Reiteration on What Reception Work Is, in Its Most Basic Form
      For Example

      Well turned out, well-kept, professional in appearance, and neat and tidy, but also keeping the reception area in the same way. Of course, your general demeanour and the way you speak to people is also key. Using your voice, language, and body language is one of the key ways to create a positive impression, ensuring repeat business in the future, word of mouth business, and also pleasing the visitor/caller at the same time.
      We will mention that big C word once more here - Confidentiality.

      Aside from creating that first impression and catering to your visitors and callers' needs, you have a huge responsibility in terms of confidentiality too. You will be privy to sensitive and private information throughout the course of your job, and it is imperative that you always exercise the measures to maintain confidentiality. Don't worry if this all sounds rather worrying at first, because the actual methods are quite often common sense, as we have discussed, and they will become second nature to you very soon after beginning your receptionist role.

      Of course, everyone is different, and it may be that you lack in one area but make up for it in others. Certain skills are more important than other ones, that's for sure, but communication and organisation are certainly two of the most important in this line of work!

Of course, your general demeanour and the way you speak to people is also key. Using your voice, language, and body language is one of the key ways to create a positive impression, ensuring repeat business in the future, word of mouth business, and also pleasing the visitor/caller at the same time.
      We will mention that big C word once more here - Confidentiality.

      Aside from creating that first impression and catering to your visitors and callers' needs, you have a huge responsibility in terms of confidentiality too. You will be privy to sensitive and private information throughout the course of your job, and it is imperative that you always exercise the measures to maintain confidentiality. Don't worry if this all sounds rather worrying at first, because the actual methods are quite often common sense, as we have discussed, and they will become second nature to you very soon after beginning your receptionist role.

    • The Key Skills and Attributes a Top Receptionist Should Have
      To give you a quick reference point, if ever you need to check back over the course during your time working as a receptionist, this is a summary of the top skills, personality traits, and attributes which an effectively and highly skilled receptionist should have.

      Of course, everyone is different, and it may be that you lack in one area but make up for it in others. Certain skills are more important than other ones, that's for sure, but communication and organisation are certainly two of the most important in this line of work!

  • Lesson Summary

  • Here are the key points in this module:
    • On a health and safety note, we do need to mention that you should always take regular breaks from the computer. Now, when working at a reception desk, you might think this is borderline impossible.
    • If you are producing written communication then it will more than likely be through the Word package.
    • Whether your organisation has a particular licence with a software company to use their program or not, you will probably use a database of some sort. Microsoft Access is one of the most popular to use.
    • Microsoft PowerPoint is a program that you may need to use if you are asked to either set up a presentation on a laptop for a meeting or if you are asked to put together an actual presentation yourself, for someone else to present.
    • Working as a team is vitally important to ensuring every task is done in the correct timescale, and to the correct standard.
    • Teamwork is basically the process of working with other people towards a common aim.
    • There is a very fine line between a professional-looking reception area that looks sterile and clinical and an area which looks professional yet welcoming.
    • As you learn your role, you shouldn't need to be babysat, and this is important in many different job roles.
    • A receptionist should be able to think on his/her feet.
